description: From Middle English drawen, draȝen, dragen (“to drag, pull, push, draw (out), go to, make, add, etc.”), from Old English dragan, from Proto-West Germanic *dragan, from Proto-Germanic *draganą, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰregʰ- (“to draw, pull”). Doublet of drag and draught.

entries.meaning: The result of a contest that neither side has won; a tie.
examples: The game ended in a draw.

entries.meaning: The procedure by which the result of a lottery is determined.
examples: The draw is on Saturday.

entries.meaning: Something that attracts e.g. a crowd.
examples: After It, Clara became one of the top box-office draws in Hollywood, but her popularity was short lived.

entries.meaning: The act of drawing.
examples: the Wild West's quick-draw champion

entries.meaning: (cricket) The result of a two-innings match in which at least one side did not complete all their innings before time ran out (as distinguished from a tie).
(golf) A golf shot that (for the right-handed player) curves intentionally to the left. See hook, slice, fade.
(curling) A shot that is intended to land gently in the house (the circular target) without knocking out other stones; cf. takeout.
(geography) A dry stream bed that drains surface water only during periods of heavy rain or flooding.
examples: The garden, curiously enough, was a quarter of a mile from the house, and the way to it led up a shallow draw past the cattle corral.

entries.meaning: (slang, countable) A bag of cannabis.
examples: So my friends and I would all chip in money to get a bag of weed or a draw.

entries.meaning: (slang, uncountable) Cannabis.
examples: Mick spoke to Simon, who was more of a drinker. He said that people who smoked draw were boring.

entries.meaning: In a commission-based job, an advance on future (potential) commissions given to an employee by the employer.
(poker) A situation in which one or more players has four cards of the same suit or four out of five necessary cards for a straight and requires a further card to make their flush or straight.
(archery) The act of pulling back the strings in preparation of firing.
(sports) The spin or twist imparted to a ball etc. by a drawing stroke.
Draft in the sense of the flow through a flue of gasses (smoke) resulting from a combustion process, possibly adjustable with a damper.
examples: She looked in [to the stove] and a tight, dismayed gasp escaped her. She slammed the door shut and adjusted the draw with trembling fingers. For a moment—just a moment—she had seen her old friend Annabelle Frane in the coals.

verbs.description: draw (third-person singular simple present draws, present participle drawing, simple past drew, past participle drawn or (colloquial and nonstandard) drew)

entries.meaning: To pull (something) in a particular manner or direction. [from 8th c.]
examples: He drew a sheaf of papers from his bag.

entries.meaning: To drag (a person, thing, or part of the body), especially along the ground. [from 10th c.]
examples: Seals  […]  throw their bodies forward, drawing their hinder-parts after them.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pull (a plough, vehicle etc.); to cause (something) to move forwards by pulling it. [from 11th c.]
(archery) To pull back (the string of a bow) in preparation for shooting. [from 12th c.]
To move (a part of one's body) in a particular direction. [from 13th c.]
examples: She settled in the window seat, drawing her leg up beneath her.

entries.meaning: To pull (a curtain, blinds etc.) open or closed. [from 13th c.]
examples: You should draw the curtains at night.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, now rare) To pull something along; to have force to move anything by pulling. [from 14th c.]
examples: This horse draws well.

entries.meaning: To pull (one's face, features) out of shape, from emotion etc. [from 14th c.]
(now rare) To construct (a wall, canal etc.) from one point to another. [from 15th c.]
examples: the huge Offa's dike which he drew from the mouth of Wye to that of Dee

entries.meaning: To require (a depth of water) for floating. [from 15th c.]
examples: A ship draws ten feet of water.

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To assume a specific position or attitude. [from 17th c.]
examples: He drew himself to his full height and glowered at the interloper.

entries.meaning: To pull (a belt or other item) so that it tightens or wraps around something more closely. [from 17th c.]
examples: She took a deep breath and drew her corset-strings.

entries.meaning: (curling) To make a shot that lands gently in the house (the circular target) without knocking out other stones. [from 18th c.]
(intransitive, now rare) To be pulled along (in a specified way). [from 19th c.]
examples: The carriage draws easily.

entries.meaning: (cricket) To play (a short-length ball directed at the leg stump) with an inclined bat so as to deflect the ball between the legs and the wicket. [from 19th c.]
(golf) To hit (the ball) with the toe of the club so that it is deflected toward the left. [from 19th c.]
(billiards) To strike (the cue ball) below the center so as to give it a backward rotation which causes it to take a backward direction on striking another ball. [from 19th c.]

definitionGroups.group: To attract, exert an influence on.

entries.meaning: To induce (the mind, eyes, attention etc.) to be directed at or focused on something. [from 9th c.]
examples: From the moment she entered the room, all eyes were drawn to her.
His mind was drawn back to the events of the preceding morning.

entries.meaning: To cause (someone) to come to a particular place, condition, or course of action; to attract (a person). [from 12th c.]
To take (air, smoke etc.) into the lungs; to inhale. [from 13th c.]
examples: I drew a deep breath and wiped my brow.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To attract (something) by means of a physical force, especially magnetism or gravity; (figurative) to act as an inducement or enticement. [from 14th c.]
To cause (something); to bring (something) about as a consequence. [from 14th c.]
To provoke or attract (a particular response or reaction). [from 16th c.]
examples: The president's comments have drawn strong criticism from rightwing media outlets.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have a draught; to allow air to be passed through in order to allow for combustion. [from 18th c.]
examples: The chimney won't draw properly if it's clogged up with soot.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To extend the duration of (something); to prolong. [10th–19th c.]
To make (wire) by pulling it through an aperture; to stretch (metal) into a wire. [from 13th c.]
examples: to draw a mass of metal into wire

entries.meaning: To stretch or elongate. [from 14th c.]
examples: The dough was run through the pasta machine and drawn into a long ribbon.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become contracted; to shrink. [from 17th c.]
(nautical) Of a sail, to fill with wind. [from 17th c.]
examples: A ship's sail is said to draw when it is filled with wind.

entries.meaning: (reflexive, now rare) To move in a specific direction. [from 12th c.]
examples: She thought she heard a noise in her chamber, and she drew herself within the casement.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, used with prepositions and adverbs) To move steadily in a particular direction or into a specific position. [from 13th c.]
examples: The runners drew level with each other as they approached the finish line.
Draw near to the fire and I will tell you a tale.
The end of the world draws near.

entries.meaning: To come to, towards (a particular moment in time); to approach (a time). [from 14th c.]
examples: As it drew towards evening, I packed up and headed for home.

entries.meaning: (hunting, now rare) To search for game; to track a quarry. [from 16th c.]
examples: On one of my expeditions, after a stormy night, at the end of March, the hounds drew all day without finding a fox.

entries.meaning: To pull out, unsheathe (a sword, firearm etc.). [from 12th c.]
examples: They drew their swords and fought each other.

entries.meaning: To take (water) from a well or other source. [from 13th c.]
examples: draw water from a well

entries.meaning: To disembowel (someone); to remove the viscera from (an animal), especially before cooking. [from 13th c.]
examples: In private draw your poultry, clean your tripe.

entries.meaning: (transitive, medicine, now rare) To extract (pus, humours, etc.) by means of medical treatment. [from 14th c.]
To select (an item) at random to decide which of a group of people will receive or undergo something; to select (a person) by this process. [from 14th c.]
examples: Provided magistracies were filled by men freely chosen or drawn.

entries.meaning: To conduct (a lottery); to select (the numbers) for a lottery; to win (a prize) in a lottery. [from 16th c.]
examples: The winning lottery numbers were drawn every Tuesday.

entries.meaning: To extract (a tooth). [from 16th c.]
To extract (juice, fluids etc.) from something by pressure, osmosis or similar. [from 16th c.]
examples: Spirits, by distillations, may be drawn out of vegetable juices, which shall flame and fume of themselves.

entries.meaning: (card games) To take or be dealt (a card) from the deck; to have (a particular hand) as a result of this. [from 16th c.]
examples: At the start of their turn, each player must draw a card.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To withdraw. [from 17th c.]
(transitive or intransitive) To end a game in a draw (with neither side winning). [from 17th c.]
examples: We drew last time we played.  I drew him last time I played him.  I drew my last game against him.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive) To steep; to leave (tea) temporarily in water to allow the flavour to increase. [from 18th c.]
examples: She made a pot of very strong tea, and while she was waiting for it to draw she opened the kitchen door to inspect her garden.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To take or be dealt a playing card from the deck. See also draw out.
examples: Jill has four diamonds; she'll try to draw for a flush.

entries.meaning: To run (a bath). [from 19th c.]
(analogous) To consume (power).
examples: The circuit draws three hundred watts.

entries.meaning: To take (something) from a particular source, especially of information; to derive. [from 13th c.]
examples: He drew comfort from the thought that he was not the first to suffer this way.
She draws her subject matter from the events of her own life.

entries.meaning: To call forth (something) from a person, to elicit. [from 14th c.]
To deduce or infer (a conclusion); to make (a deduction). [from 16th c.]
examples: He tried to draw a conclusion from the facts.

entries.meaning: To receive (a salary); to withdraw (money) from a bank etc. [from 16th c.]
examples: to draw money from a bank

entries.meaning: To elicit information from (someone); to induce (a person) to speak on some subject. (Now frequently in passive.) [from 19th c.]
examples: He refused to be drawn on the subject

entries.meaning: (transitive) To produce (a shape, figure, picture etc.) with pencil, crayon, chalk, or other implement. [from 14th c.]
examples: A crude picture had been drawn on the wall of his poky apartment.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To depict (something) linguistically; to portray in words. [from 14th c.]
examples: Her first novel contained a host of characters who were richly and convincingly drawn.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To draw up, compose (a document). [from 14th c.]
examples: to draw a memorial, a deed, or bill of exchange

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To produce an image of something by artistic means; to make drawings. [from 15th c.]
examples: When I came in she was drawing on a big piece of coloured paper.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To produce a visual representation of (a person or thing) by lines and marks with pencil, pen, paints etc. [from 16th c.]
